revised_title: Ritualization of Behaviour in Animals and Man: Development of Courtship Displays in Junglefowl
tldr: This study examines the development of courtship displays in Junglefowl, focusing on the intricate and highly stereotyped display activities of adult male Junglefowl, such as waltzing, tidbitting, and cornering. The author investigates how these displays develop ontogenetically and whether external conditions play a role in their development. The study finds that social behavior develops in a regular and predictable sequence, starting at a simple level and becoming more complex. Courtship displays are mainly due to conflicts between aggression and escape tendencies, and the development of these tendencies depends on social experience.
